title: SB 1.19.39-40 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 06-06-2023 | Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: As you might be aware, Bhagavatam is divided into 12 cantos, skandha in Sanskrit.
segments.summary: HH Stoka Krishna Swami introduces the Srimad Bhagavatam, explaining its structure of 12 cantos, chapters, and verses, highlighting the significance of the 10th canto which focuses on Krishna Leela.
segments.transcript: Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya Narayanam Namaskritya Naram Chai Vanarottamam Devi Saraswati Vyasam Tato Jayam Udi Rayet. In this session, we will be discussing two verses, the 39th and the 40th verses of the 19th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. These are the last two verses in this chapter, and with the end of this chapter, even the first canto comes to an end. So these are the last two verses of this entire canto itself of the Srimad Bhagavatam. As you might be aware, Bhagavatam is divided into 12 cantos, skandha in Sanskrit, and each of those cantos have got many chapters, and each chapter has got many verses. So totally, the number of verses is 18,000 in the Srimad Bhagavatam, and the number of cantos is 12, and there are different number of chapters in each canto. Just like this first canto has 19 chapters, the second canto has 10 chapters, whereas the 10th canto has got 90 chapters, 9-0, the biggest canto. Why? Because the 10th canto exclusively describes Krishna Leela. The other cantos describe the pastimes of the other incarnations of the Supreme Lord, and even the pastimes of the activities of the devotees of the Supreme Lord, including the devotees of Krishna like the Pandavas.

segments.key_quote: In the Vedic culture, even the poorest of the householders keep at least 10 cows.
segments.summary: The lecture delves into the meaning of verse 39, discussing the Vedic culture where householders maintain cows and provide milk to mendicants, emphasizing the self-sufficiency and charitable nature of this lifestyle.
segments.transcript: So, 39th verse. The meaning of this 39th verse is, "O powerful Brahmana! It is said that you hardly stay in the houses of men long enough to milk a cow." Shukadeva Goswami has appeared in that assembly. Now, what is the duration for which if Shukadeva Goswami goes to somebody's house? So, Prabhupada explains this in the purport. Saints and sages in the renounced order of life go to the houses of householders. At the time, they milk the cows early in the morning and ask some quantity of milk for subsistence. Even though somebody will be completely renounced from everything material, as long as this body is there, for the bodily maintenance, at least devotees, they beg for some milk. And from whom do they beg? From the householders who keep cows. That's the Vedic culture generally. Vedic culture means the householders generally keep at least one cow or a few cows, and they have some land for growing some food. Very easily all economic necessities can be met by having some land for cultivation of food grains, vegetables, growing some flowers or fruits, and also having one or more cows. So, Prabhupada says the householders are able to not only get enough for themselves, but if some saintly person comes begging, Bhavati bhikshan dehi, they want very little, little milk. So the householders can easily give that little milk. So, Prabhupada says a pound of milk fresh from the milk bag of a cow is sufficient to feed an adult with all vitamin values, and therefore saints and sages live only on milk. Very, very easy. They take some milk, drink that, and that's enough to give them all necessary nutrition for their subsistence, for engaging in devotional service exclusively, without the need for gathering some grains, cooking it, preparing some foodstuff. Either oneself or somebody else has to prepare nothing. Directly take the milk, especially when milk is being taken from the cow, the cow is being milked, just take that milk, drink it, finished, over. So, Prabhupada says in the Vedic culture, even the poorest of the householders keep at least 10 cows. This is Vedic culture, each delivering 12 to 20 quarts of milk, and therefore no one hesitates to spare a few pounds of milk for the mendicants.

themes: Importance of association with saintly persons
segments.key_quote: So, to take advantage of the saintly persons coming for begging is the real business of a householder.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that saintly persons stay only briefly, and householders should use that opportunity to gain spiritual knowledge, emphasizing the importance of association with saints.

So, when they have ten cows, each of those cows can give so much milk, and they have plenty of milk to even spare for, even the poorest of householders is considered poor householders. They can spare some milk for the saintly persons who come begging. Anybody can give. So, Srila Prabhupada says it is the duty of householders to maintain the saints and sages like the children, like their own children. They give some milk at least to those who come begging for some milk, milk or food. So, a saint like Shukadeva Goswami would hardly stay at the house of a householder, for he would hardly stay for more than five minutes. He would hardly stay for more than five minutes. That means he would not even stay for five minutes at the house of a householder. So, what does this mean? In other words, such saints are rarely, very rarely seen in the houses of householders, very rarely. If at all they approach a householder, little milk, less than five minutes. When they are milking the cow, just take little milk and go on. So, therefore, Maharaj Pariksit therefore prayed to Shukadeva Goswami to instruct him as soon as possible. So, Raupar is giving us a lot of instructions here. Householders should understand saintly persons when they come begging, they are not going to stay for long. So, to take advantage of the saintly persons coming for begging is the real business of a householder, the real duty of a householder.

themes: Reciprocal relationship between saints and householders

segments.key_quote: One who is a pure devotee of Krishna, he has got all the good qualities that are to be found in even the devatas. All the good qualities.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses verse 40, highlighting the qualities of King Pariksit as a devotee and his ability to ask perfect questions, setting the stage for Shukadeva Goswami's reply in the next canto.
segments.transcript: saints and the householders. The 40th verse, the last verse, the meaning of this verse is, "Shree Sruthi Goswami said, the king thus spoke and questioned the sage using sweet language. Then the great and powerful personality, the son of Vyasa Deva, who knew the principles of religion, began his reply after hearing the question just asked very sweetly, very nicely." His Pariksit himself is a great devotee. The devotee is qualified in multiple ways. He can ask the perfect and precise question. He can ask the question in very sweet words. He is well behaved. So this is another fact about a devotee. One who is a pure devotee of Krishna, he has got all the good qualities that are to be found in even the devatas. All the good qualities. So therefore, Pariksit asked the perfect question of perfect questions, and Shikudai Goswami, who is the great and powerful personality, who knew the principles of religion, Dharmagya, he began his reply.
